Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scholarships are being awarded to ten first-year students and ten second-year students working full-time toward their Associate in Science Degree in the Cyber Security Option. The Cyber Security Scholarship Program is designed to create student cohorts through academic support services and social activities. These services and activities enable the students to bond and provide peer support. Activities and services include tutoring, study hall sessions, mentoring, support groups, transfer assistance, career counseling, service-learning opportunities, and development of a student club.

Intellectual Merit: Led by highly qualified faculty, the college is the only two-year college in the nation offering all five cyber security credentialing programs. The Cyber Security Scholarship Program enables faculty to recruit, educate, and train cyber security professionals. Graduates work for private financial institutions and government agencies such as the Federal Aviation Administration and Department of Defense.

Broader Impacts: The Cyber Security Scholarship Program is building upon current college, state, and national cyber security programs including the Oklahoma Center for Information Assurance and Forensics Education Consortium (OCIAFE). It works to expand the participation of underrepresented groups within computer forensics. With one of the most diverse student enrollments in the state of Oklahoma, the college is continuing to work on recruiting underrepresented groups and underprivileged individuals to create a well-trained and diverse workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) grant awarded to Rose State College has assisted in providing educational opportunities for 285 academically talented and financially needy students to be trained and introduced into the Cyber Security workforce. Of these 285 students, 84% have gone on to continue their education by pursuing 4 year degrees in related fields.

The introduction of this NSF grant enabled the Cyber Security program at Rose State College to grow by over 42% during the span of the grant. Additional classes have been added along with additional faculty members hired to support this growth.

100% of scholarship funds awarded to Rose State College were expended and awarded to students.

100% of the 285 grant students maintained or increased their Grade Point Average (GPA) while receiving funding from this NSF grant. Active monitoring of grades, tutoring, mentoring, and additional support services were used to ensure success of all students.

89% of the 285 grant students graduated within 2 years of receiving the grant compared to the Rose State College institutional average of 8%.

99% of the 285 grant students graduated within 3 years which is again above the Rose State College institutional average of 18.8%.

79% of the 285 grant students found employment in a related field or occupation. 

Many of the 285 grant students were nontraditional students that came to either retrain or pursue a new field of study allowing them to graduate in less than 2 years. Out of the full-time, traditional students, 76% persisted from fall to fall which is 22% higher from the institutional rate of 54%. Many of our students who were provided scholarships graduated in less than two years due to already having 30 or more credits upon entering the scholarship.

The Cyber Security program at Rose State College, through funding from the NSF, has continued to grow. In the fall of 2017, the largest number of declared cyber security majors ever at Rose State College (242) was reported. The 242 declared cyber security majors is up from 170 at the start of the grant in the fall of 2011. This represents over a 42% increase in growth over the life of the grant.

The NSF grant has helped to attract higher quality of students. This has enabled the RSC cyber security program to provide quality students to the new Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the University of Tulsa, which is under the direction of Dr. Sujeet Shenoi.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2018
Modified by: Kenneth C Dewey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The National Science Foundation (NSF) grant awarded to Rose State College has assisted in providing educational opportunities for 285 academically talented and financially needy students to be trained and introduced into the Cyber Security workforce. Of these 285 students, 84% have gone on to continue their education by pursuing 4 year degrees in related fields. The introduction of this NSF grant enabled the Cyber Security program at Rose State College to grow by over 42% during the span of the grant. Additional classes have been added along with additional faculty members hired to support this growth. 100% of scholarship funds awarded to Rose State College were expended and awarded to students. 100% of the 285 grant students maintained or increased their Grade Point Average (GPA) while receiving funding from this NSF grant. Active monitoring of grades, tutoring, mentoring, and additional support services were used to ensure success of all students. 89% of the 285 grant students graduated within 2 years of receiving the grant compared to the Rose State College institutional average of 8%. 99% of the 285 grant students graduated within 3 years which is again above the Rose State College institutional average of 18.8%. 79% of the 285 grant students found employment in a related field or occupation. Many of the 285 grant students were nontraditional students that came to either retrain or pursue a new field of study allowing them to graduate in less than 2 years. Out of the full-time, traditional students, 76% persisted from fall to fall which is 22% higher from the institutional rate of 54%. Many of our students who were provided scholarships graduated in less than two years due to already having 30 or more credits upon entering the scholarship. The Cyber Security program at Rose State College, through funding from the NSF, has continued to grow. In the fall of 2017, the largest number of declared cyber security majors ever at Rose State College (242) was reported. The 242 declared cyber security majors is up from 170 at the start of the grant in the fall of 2011. This represents over a 42% increase in growth over the life of the grant. The NSF grant has helped to attract higher quality of students. This has enabled the RSC cyber security program to provide quality students to the new Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the University of Tulsa, which is under the direction of Dr. Sujeet Shenoi.
